required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: GOOD-DAY: Efficacy of Gamification of an educatiOnal Training tO meDiterranean Diet on Weight and Metabolic Control in pAediatric obesitY: a Pilot Open-label Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Azienda Ospedaliero Universitaria Maggiore della Carita

clinical_study.source: Azienda Ospedaliero Universitaria Maggiore della Carita

brief_summary.textblock: Alongside efforts in public health and policy to reverse the childhood obesity epidemic, medical providers seek to play effective roles in prevention and treatment. Limited interventional studies with effective long-term maintenance of weight loss in children are available. Moreover, interventions should focus on modifying lifestyle, by improving also ludic educational training. In fact, the knowledge, attitudes, behaviors and skills developed through effective health programs may result in a better quality of life and empower children to make correct choices to promote the health of the individual the family and the community. For this reason, in a cohort of obese pediatric subjects with visceral adiposity, the aim of the study is to assess the efficacy of an educational training inspired to Mediterranean diet and based on gamification (as "The Mediterranean Goose") with respect to a conventional treatment on weight loss and improvement of cardio-metabolic risk factors.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline BMI at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline HOMA-IR at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement of cardio-metabolic risk factors: insulin resistance (HOMA-IR)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline lipid profile at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement of cardio-metabolic risk factors: lipid profile

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline blood pressure at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement of cardio-metabolic risk factors: arterial hypertension

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline KIDMED Index at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Adherence to Mediterranean Diet, evaluating food and habits questionnaires

arm_group.description: These subjects will receive a standard diet according to routine clinical practice + a 30 minutes Mediterranean-Style Diet educational training with explanation of Mediterranean pyramid + gamification to Mediterranean diet inside the Hospital and at home throughout "The Mediterranean Goose".

These subjects will receive Standard Diet according to routine care and practice. The standard diet will be distributed with 55-60% of carbohydrates (45-50% complex and no more than 10% refined and processed sugars), 25-30% lipids and 15% proteins, and will be performedin accordance with the calories of an isocaloric balanced diet calculated throughout the Italian LARN Guidelines for age and gender (Società Italiana di Nutrizione Umana, 2014), inspired to Mediterranean pyramid.

intervention.description: The intervention consists in a standard diet according to routine clinical practice + a 30 minutes Mediterranean-Style Diet educational training with explanation of Mediterranean pyramid + gamification to Mediterranean diet inside the Hospital and at home throughout "The Mediterranean Goose".

facility.name: Pediatric Endocrine Service of AOU Maggiore della Carità of Novara; SCDU of Pediatrics, Department of Health Sciences, University of Eastern Piedmont

link.description: "Mediterranean diet and enhancement of traditional foodstuff - MedDiet"
